description: From Middle English speche, from Old English spǣċ, sprǣċ (“speech, discourse, language”), from Proto-West Germanic *sprāku (“speech, language”), from Proto-Indo-European *spereg-, *spreg- (“to make a sound”). Cognate with Dutch spraak (“speech”), German Sprache (“language, speech”). More at speak.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The ability to speak; the faculty of uttering words or articulate sounds and vocalizations to communicate.
examples: He had a bad speech impediment.
After the accident she lost her speech.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The act of speaking, a certain style of it.
examples: It was hard to hear his speech over the noise.
Her speech was soft and lilting.

entries.meaning: (countable) A formal session of speaking, especially a long oral message given publicly by one person.
examples: Synonyms: address, allocution, monologue, oration, soliloquy
The candidate made some ambitious promises in his campaign speech.

entries.meaning: (countable) A dialect, vernacular, or (dated) a language.
(uncountable) Language used orally, rather than in writing.
examples: This word is mostly used in speech.

entries.meaning: (grammar) An utterance that is quoted; see direct speech, reported speech

verbs.description: speech (third-person singular simple present speeches, present participle speeching, simple past and past participle speeched)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To make a speech; to harangue.
examples: I'll speech against peace while Dismal's my name, /  And be a true whig, while I'm Not-in-game.
